qas.question: What can be done when small amounts of lead are added to alloys?
What is made with an alloy of 4% aluminium mixed with 96% zinc?
Why are alloys used to make stamping dies rather than metal?
Why isn't unalloyed zinc used in construction applications?
What can be done when large amounts of lead are added to alloys?
What is made with an alloy of 4% magic mixed with 96% zinc?
Why are alloys used to make metal rather than stamping dies?
Why is unalloyed zinc used in construction applications?

context: Similar alloys with the addition of a small amount of lead can be <a0_0><b4_0>cold-rolled into sheets<b4_0/><a0_0/>. An alloy of 96% zinc and 4% aluminium is used to make <a1_0><b5_0>stamping dies<b5_0/><a1_0/> for low production run applications for which ferrous metal dies would be <a2_0><b6_0>too expensive<b6_0/><a2_0/>. In building facades, roofs or other applications in which zinc is used as sheet metal and for methods such as deep drawing, roll forming or bending, zinc alloys with titanium and copper are used. Unalloyed zinc is <a3_0>too <b7_0>brittle<b7_0/><a3_0/> for these kinds of manufacturing processes.
